articles.headline: Wary of Protests, Exxon Plans Natural Gas Terminal in the Atlantic
articles.snippet: The company said Tuesday that it would like to build a $1 billion floating terminal for liquefied natural gas about 20 miles off the coast of New Jersey.
articles.abstract: The company said Tuesday that it would like to build a $1 billion floating terminal for liquefied natural gas about 20 miles off the coast of New Jersey.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil said Tuesday that it would like to build a $1 billion floating terminal for liquefied natural gas about 20 miles off the coast of New Jersey, a move meant to deflect safety and environmental concerns about proximity to populated areas.

articles.headline: President Pick Would Name Putin Premier
articles.snippet: If the scenario outlined by Dmitri A. Medvedev plays out, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would still wield power.
articles.abstract: If the scenario outlined by Dmitri A. Medvedev plays out, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would still wield power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  The longtime aide tapped by Vladimir V. Putin to be his successor as president of Russia declared Tuesday that he wanted Mr. Putin to be his prime minister, offering the clearest indication yet of how Mr. Putin plans to maintain firm control over the Kremlin after his term ends next spring.

articles.headline: Trial of Cholesterol Drug Gets House Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.
articles.abstract: A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Congressional committee is investigating Merck and Schering-Plough for their handling of a critical clinical trial of Zetia, their blockbuster cholesterol-lowering drug.

articles.headline: Twin Bombs Kill Dozens in Algiers
articles.snippet: Two car bombs exploded in quick succession near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building.
articles.abstract: Two car bombs exploded in quick succession near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS  Twin car bombs near United Nations offices and an Algerian government building killed dozens of people Tuesday in what may have been the deadliest attack here in more than a decade.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Craig S. Smith

articles.headline: Recent Arrival at Citi Now Runs It
articles.snippet: Vikram S. Pandit confronts the daunting task of shoring up the company, which has been brought to its knees by the mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: Vikram S. Pandit confronts the daunting task of shoring up the company, which has been brought to its knees by the mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit joined Citigroup six months ago to oversee one part of the giant bank. Now, he confronts a far more daunting task: shoring up the entire company, which has been pummeled by the mortgage crisis and the recent turmoil in the credit markets.

articles.headline: Credit Crisis Prompts Fed to Roll Back Rates Again
articles.snippet: In announcing the cut, the Federal Reserve signaled its concern that the credit crisis may be damaging the broader economy. The Dow fell nearly 300 points.
articles.abstract: In announcing the cut, the Federal Reserve signaled its concern that the credit crisis may be damaging the broader economy. The Dow fell nearly 300 points.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark short-term interest rate Tuesday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 4.25 percent, and suggested that it would lower rates again if the credit crisis continued to damage not just housing, but the rest of the economy as well.

articles.headline: Seeking Leaders, U.S. Companies Think Globally
articles.snippet: The corner offices of corporate America’s largest companies are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.
articles.abstract: The corner offices of corporate America’s largest companies are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The corner offices of corporate America are increasingly being filled from every corner of the world.

articles.headline: The Capital of Slumping Home Sales
articles.snippet: The standoff between buyers and sellers in Paramount, Calif.,  helps explain why we’re still a long way from the bottom of the real estate cycle.
articles.abstract: The standoff between buyers and sellers in Paramount, Calif.,  helps explain why we’re still a long way from the bottom of the real estate cycle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just south of Los Angeles, there is a small city called Paramount where houses have all but stopped selling.

articles.headline: Remaking The Journal
articles.snippet: Although Rupert Murdoch just completed his purchase of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, on Thursday, his influence is already apparent.
articles.abstract: Although Rupert Murdoch just completed his purchase of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, on Thursday, his influence is already apparent.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few months, Rupert Murdoch has moved into an office at Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal. He has pushed the paper’s editors for shorter articles and more hard news. He has personally wooed reporters he wants to keep out of his competitors’ hands.

articles.headline: Feeling Heat, Clinton Tries Iowa Up Close
articles.snippet: Nowhere are Hillary Rodham Clinton’s problems on display more than in Iowa.
articles.abstract: Nowhere are Hillary Rodham Clinton’s problems on display more than in Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  Ten months ago, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton went to East High School here on her first trip to Iowa as a presidential candidate and laid out a case for her candidacy to a cheering crowd in a packed gymnasium.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: On Taliban Turf, Long Lines of Ailing Children
articles.snippet: Health problems among children are aggravated by the harsh edicts of the Taliban in their remote strongholds.
articles.abstract: Health problems among children are aggravated by the harsh edicts of the Taliban in their remote strongholds.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARAWADDIN, Afghanistan  The Afghan boy crouched near a wall in this remote village, where the Taliban’s strength has prevented the government from providing services. His eyes were coated by an opaque yellow sheath.
